CatDescriptText: Mr. Curtis L. Davis, porter, Robinson Township and Mr. William Singleton, hotel worker, East Liberty, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 18, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think Negroes in Pittsburgh are as progressive as those in other metropolitan cities like New Your, Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland, San Francisco, and Los Angeles? Why?"   Mr. Davis' answer reads: "I believe Negroes are doing better in Chicago, Detroit, and other cities, because they hire Negroes in more jobs in those cities than here.  As a result, Negroes progress much faster..."  Mr. Singleton's answer reads: "No, I don't, because here, Negroes don't have good jobs mainly because of discrimination."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Curtis L. Davis wearing light colored cap, eyeglasses, and flecked and grid patterned overcoat with upturned collar, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of William Singleton wearing dark fedora, moustache, and plaid overcoat, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
